sequence.notes: Selective monotosylation of a symmetric 2,2-dimethylpropane-1,3-diol. The central carbon is achiral despite the stereochemical wedges/dashes, as it bears two identical methyl groups and two identical hydroxymethyl/tosyloxymethyl groups.
Nucleophilic substitution of a primary tosylate with thiophenol, activated by sodium hydride to form the thiophenoxide anion.
Oxidation of a phenyl sulfide to a phenyl sulfone, retaining stereochemistry at the adjacent quaternary carbon.
Primary alcohol is oxidized to an aldehyde using Swern oxidation conditions.
Grignard addition of a pentenylmagnesium bromide to an aldehyde, forming a new secondary alcohol and retaining existing stereochemistry.
Oxidation of a secondary alcohol to a ketone using Swern conditions.
Terminal alkene dihydroxylation to a vicinal diol.
Oxidative cleavage of a 1,2-diol to an aldehyde, with loss of a one-carbon fragment (likely formaldehyde). The secondary alcohol is oxidized to an aldehyde, and the primary alcohol is lost.
Asymmetric aldol addition of a chiral ketone enolate to an aldehyde, forming a beta-hydroxy ketone.

substeps.notes: The reactant is (E)-4-phenyl-3-methylbut-3-en-2-ol, drawn without stereochemistry at the alcohol carbon. The product is (2S,E)-4-phenyl-3-methylbut-3-en-2-ol, with specific (S) stereochemistry at the alcohol carbon and retaining the (E) double bond. Although the reaction description states 'Sharpless asymmetric epoxidation', the product structure in the screenshot is an allylic alcohol with defined stereochemistry, not an epoxide.
Ozonolysis of an E-alkene to a ketone, cleaving the phenyl-substituted carbon. The chiral center is retained with R-configuration.

sequence.notes: Samarium diiodide-mediated reductive coupling of the alpha-carbon of the terminal ketone with p-nitrobenzaldehyde, reducing the ketone to a secondary alcohol and forming a new C-C bond at the former alpha-position.
Protection of a secondary alcohol as a tert-butyldimethylsilyl (TBS) ether.
Deprotection of p-nitrobenzoate ester to alcohol. The yield is for 2 steps.

Intramolecular acid-catalyzed cyclization of a keto-alcohol to a dihydropyran, involving elimination of the sulfonyl group to form a double bond. Stereochemistry at the OPMB group is inverted during the reaction. The stereochemistry depicted for the methyl group on the double bond of the product is inconsistent with an sp2 hybridized carbon and has been omitted in the SMILES.

Deprotonation of alpha-sulfonyl C-H of the reactant with n-BuLi, followed by nucleophilic addition of the resulting carbanion to the aldehyde of the reagent. This forms a new carbon-carbon bond and a lithium alkoxide.

substeps.notes: Sharpless asymmetric epoxidation of a primary allylic alcohol to form a trans-epoxide.
Protection of a primary alcohol as its triisopropylsilyl (TIPS) ether.
Birch reduction of a substituted epoxide, reducing the aromatic ring and opening the epoxide to form a secondary alcohol.
Ozonolysis of a 1,4-cyclohexadiene derivative followed by reductive workup (DMS). The yield reported is for 3 steps.
Stereoselective reduction of a β-keto ester to a 1,3-diol. The existing chiral center influences the stereochemistry of the newly formed alcohol.
Acid-catalyzed intramolecular lactonization of a methyl ester and diol, forming a delta-lactone.
Selective silylation of the secondary alcohol with TESCl in the presence of an existing TIPS ether, preserving both stereocenters.
Nucleophilic addition of benzyloxymethyllithium to a lactone, followed by intramolecular hemiacetal formation.
Selective deprotection of TES group to hydroxyl and reductive cleavage of anomeric OBn group to CH2OBn via Kishi reduction.
Deprotection of a TIPS ether to a primary alcohol.
Silylation of two hydroxyl groups with TBSOTf to form TBS ethers.
Benzyl ether cleaved to primary alcohol. Reaction yield stated as '83% (3 steps)', indicating this might be the last step of a multi-step sequence.
Primary alcohol is oxidized to an aldehyde using Swern oxidation conditions, while TBS protecting groups remain intact.

sequence.notes: Acetylation of a lithium alkoxide to form an acetate ester.
Sulfone-mediated olefination where an acetate and sulfone are eliminated to form an E-alkene.
Deprotection of a primary tert-butyldimethylsilyl (TBS) ether to a primary alcohol using TBAF.
Conversion of a primary alcohol to a triflate (trifluoromethanesulfonate) using triflic anhydride and 2,6-lutidine.

Intramolecular alkylation of a vinyl triflate with a sulfone-stabilized carbanion, leading to cyclization and a new C-C bond formation, followed by sulfone elimination to form a new pyran ring and a hydroxyl group.

substeps.notes: An Evans asymmetric aldol reaction between an aldehyde and a chloroacetylated Evans auxiliary, leading to the formation of an aldol product with three new stereocenters.
Reductive dechlorination of an alpha-chloro ketone derivative using zinc metal.
Reductive cleavage of a chiral oxazolidinone auxiliary and reduction of the terminal carbonyl to a primary alcohol. The overall transformation is indicated to proceed in 3 steps.

Formation of a 1,3-dioxane cyclic acetal from a 1,3-diol and an acetal (PMPCH(OMe)2) under acidic conditions (PPTS). All existing stereocenters are preserved, and a new chiral center is formed at the acetal carbon.
Reductive cleavage of a 1,3-dioxane acetal (PMP acetal) to a primary alcohol and p-methoxybenzyl ether. (2 steps)
Primary alcohol is oxidized to an aldehyde via Swern oxidation. All stereocenters and other functional groups remain unchanged.

An aldehyde undergoes an aldol reaction with a ketene silyl acetal, promoted by a titanium catalyst, to form a β-hydroxy-β-keto ester derivative. Stereochemistry at the newly formed hydroxyl group is specific (indicated as 'up'). The existing stereocenters and alkene geometry are preserved.
Stereoselective reduction of a beta-keto ester to a 1,3-diol using tetramethylammonium triacetoxyborohydride.

Intramolecular lactonization of a methyl ester with a hydroxyl group, catalyzed by PPTS, leading to a 6-membered lactone ring. Stereochemistry of PMB-protected alcohol and remaining free alcohol is preserved. The methyl ester is consumed, and one hydroxyl group forms the lactone oxygen, while another hydroxyl group remains.
Protection of the secondary hydroxyl group on the lactone ring as a tert-butyldimethylsilyl (TBS) ether using TBSOTf and 2,6-lutidine.
Lactone ring opening with aniline (as aniline hydrochloride), activated by trimethylaluminum, forms a linear amide with a new hydroxyl group. The TBS and PMB protecting groups are retained.
Alkene undergoes ozonolysis, followed by intramolecular cyclization of the newly formed aldehyde with a hydroxyl group to form a cyclic hemiacetal.
Acetylation of a secondary alcohol to an acetate ester using acetic anhydride and pyridine.
Displacement of the acetate group by a phenylthio group, proceeding with inversion of stereochemistry at the reaction center.
Oxidation of a phenyl thioether to a phenyl sulfone. The reported yield is for 3 steps.

sequence.notes: Silylation of a secondary alcohol with TESCl.
Secondary amine (N-phenyl amide) is protected as an N-Boc amide using Boc₂O and DMAP in acetonitrile. Several silyl protecting groups (TBS, TES) and PMB ethers are present and remain unchanged.
The Boc-protected amide is hydrolyzed and then transesterified with benzyl alkoxide to form a benzyl ester. Yield is given for 2 steps.
Epoxidation of the internal C=C double bond in the dihydropyran ring to form an alpha-epoxide using m-CPBA.
Acid-catalyzed nucleophilic ring opening of a spiro-epoxide with methanol, forming an alcohol and a methyl ether.
Oxidation of a secondary alcohol to a ketone using Dess-Martin periodinane.

The reaction involves the deprotection of all silyl ethers (TBSO, OTES, OTBS) and one OPMB group, along with a complex rearrangement where a ketone and an adjacent methoxy group are transformed into an alcohol and a new ring system. The other OPMB, OBn ester, and one OMe group remain.
Two hydroxyl groups are protected as triethylsilyl (TES) ethers.

Benzyl ester is deprotected to carboxylic acid using Pd/C and 1,4-cyclohexadiene. Protecting groups TES (Triethylsilyl) and PMB (p-Methoxybenzyl) are retained. The provided reactant SMILES is missing one [TES] group (the one depicted as OTES in the lower-middle part of the structure in the screenshot). The provided product SMILES has two [TES] groups, but the second [TES] group (that corresponds to OTES in the screenshot) is depicted as being attached to the same carbon as the carboxylic acid chain (e.g., C[CH](COOH)[TES]), which is topologically incorrect based on the screenshot where OTES is on the furan ring and the COOH chain is on the cyclohexane ring. The original product SMILES also incorrectly shortened the carboxylic acid chain (CC(=O)O instead of CCCC(=O)O), which has been corrected in the output product SMILES. Due to these fundamental topological errors in the provided SMILES that cannot be resolved by simple string manipulation, the output SMILES for both reactant and product still contain discrepancies with the screenshot regarding the position/presence of the second TES group, as noted.
Yamaguchi lactonization of a carboxylic acid and secondary alcohol to form a 7-membered lactone.

Selective deprotection of the top-left TES ether to a hydroxyl group. The other TES and PMB protecting groups remain intact. The provided reactant SMILES is missing the 'OTES' group shown at the bottom-right of the reactant structure in the screenshot, implying the input reactant SMILES is structurally incomplete relative to the image. Consequently, the corrected reactant and product SMILES also reflect this missing group.

Oxidation of a secondary alcohol to a ketone. The original SMILES had expanded PMB and TES groups, which were abbreviated. A junk fragment `(OC)(OC)OC)` was removed. The representation of the other two methoxy groups in the original SMILES was complex and potentially ambiguous; the corrected SMILES reflects the most likely interpretation after removing the identified junk, but the full accuracy of all OMe group placements cannot be guaranteed without a complete re-generation from structure.
Horner-Wadsworth-Emmons olefination of a macrocyclic ketone to form an E-alpha,beta-unsaturated methyl ester.

An aldol addition reaction of methyl glyoxylate to the alpha-carbon (C22, Evans numbering) of the C23 ketone. The stereochemistry at C22 is inverted from (S) to (R), and a new chiral center with (S) configuration is formed on the added group.

The reaction involves the dehydration of an alpha-hydroxy methyl ester (CH(OH)CO2Me) to an alpha,beta-unsaturated methyl ester (C(CO2Me)=C(Me)) within a 7-membered lactone ring. The reactant has a specific connectivity where the CH(OH)CO2Me group is directly bonded to a CH(Me) group, and both are part of the lactone ring, which is connected to a quaternary carbon (with Me and OMe). However, the provided reactant SMILES `[C@]4(C(=O)C(C[C@@H](C[C@H]([C@@H](C)[OPMB])OC(=O)C1)O4)C(C(=O)OC)O)OC)` implies that the CH(OH)CO2Me group and the CH(Me) group (represented within the `C[C@@H](...)O4)` fragment) are both branched directly off the quaternary carbon `[C@]4`. This is a topological mismatch with the screenshot, where they are adjacent in the ring. The product SMILES provided was significantly garbled, containing redundant fragments and an incorrect number of TES groups. Due to the fundamental structural error in the provided reactant SMILES at the reaction site, and the severe corruption of the provided product SMILES, a precise string-based correction reflecting the chemical transformation was not possible. The reactant SMILES has been corrected only for abbreviations. The product SMILES has been cleaned of obvious junk and abbreviations applied, but remains topologically inconsistent with the visual representation.

The reaction involves the asymmetric reduction of a ketone to an alcohol, followed by acylation with a methoxyacetyl group. Triethylsilyl (TES) and p-methoxybenzyl (PMB) protecting groups are present and retained. The chiral catalyst is a methyl-CBS-oxazaborolidine derivative, and the acylating agent is Methoxyacetyl Anhydride (derived from 'MeOAc2O' text and product structure).
Hydrolysis of a triethylsilyl (TES) ether to a hydroxyl group.

Deprotection of a methoxyacetyl ester to a hydroxyl group using sodium carbonate in methanol. The provided SMILES for both reactant and product contain significant embedded structural errors, such as multiple methoxy groups at a single carbon (e.g., C(OMe)3 where only one OMe or OH is present) and spurious repetition of complex structural motifs (e.g., an extra lactone-like chain and a third PMB group in the product). These deep errors cannot be fully corrected through simple string manipulations and would require re-generation of the SMILES from the image. The corrections above address disconnected junk fragments and the specific chemical transformation, while preserving the complex but possibly erroneous core structure.
Acid-catalyzed deprotection of a methyl ether (OMe) to a hydroxyl group (OH). The reaction proceeds over 3 steps.
Esterification of the C-22 hydroxyl group of Bryostatin 2 analog with (E,E)-2,4-octadienoic acid.
DDQ mediated deprotection of two p-methoxybenzyl (PMB) protecting groups to yield two hydroxyl groups. The two triethylsilyl (TES) ethers are stable under these conditions.
